chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A workable reform is to keep the Electoral College’s state-based framework but make it operate more like a national tally: require every state to allocate electors by the same proportional formula and eliminate the “bonus” from winner‑take‑all. Add a majority-winner backstop—ranked-choice voting or a uniform runoff rule—so the president wins with broad support rather than a narrow plurality. To strengthen legitimacy, pair these changes with enforceable elector-binding rules and clear national minimum standards for ballot access, paper-backed tabulation, risk-limiting audits, and automatic recount triggers in close races.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should keep states administering presidential elections and preserve a meaningful regional balance, but reduce winner-take-all distortions so outcomes better reflect how people vote in every state and campaigns aren’t dominated by a few battlegrounds. A practical bridge is to require proportional (or carefully designed district-based, anti-gerrymandered) allocation of electors, with electors legally bound to the result, and to consider a majority-winner safeguard like ranked-choice voting. Whatever model is chosen, uniform national baselines for ballot access, paper-backed audits, and clear automatic recount triggers would make close elections more transparent, calm, and trusted.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should make presidential elections feel fair in every state—so more votes matter, campaigns aren’t dominated by a few battlegrounds, and results are easy to verify and accept. A practical compromise is to keep state-run elections but end winner-take-all by requiring proportional allocation of electors, while binding electors to the certified vote and using an independent, nonpartisan method to draw any district lines if states choose a district-based option. Pair this with clear national baselines for ballot access, multilingual voter information, paper-backed audits, and automatic recount triggers in close races, and consider ranked-choice voting or a runoff to ensure the winner has majority support.
